TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, smectitic Ustic Glossocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Vulcan very gravelly sandy loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.)
01--4 to 1 inch; undecomposed organic material, chiefly needles, bark, twigs, and leaves.
02--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed organic material like that of the horizon above.
A2--0 to 8 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) very gravelly sandy loam, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) moist weak thin platy structure that parts to fine granules; soft, very friable; 60 percent gravel; slightly acid; gradual irregular boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
A&B--8 to 16 inches; mixed light gray (10YR 7/2) and reddish brown (10YR 5/4) very stony sandy clay loam (composite texture), light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) and reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable, slightly sticky slightly plastic; peds are very hard, firm; this horizon contains seams and nodules of clayey material like that of the underlying horizon imbedded in a matrix like that of the overlying horizon; few thin patchy clay films on some of the more clayey peds; 60 percent stones; medium acid; gradual wavy boundary.  (3 to 10 inches thick)
B2t--16 to 36 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) very stony clay, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium and fine subangular and angular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, sticky plastic; peds are extremely hard, very firm; thin continuous clay films on peds and in root channels and pores; 60 percent stones; medium acid; gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 20 inches thick)
IIC--36 to 60 inches; fragmental deposits of fractured rhyolite bedrock, consisting mainly of overlapping rhyolite flagstone that may or may not be oriented to the horizontal axis, and with voids 1 to 4 inches across that are not filled with fine materials.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Saguache County, Colorado; near the southwest corner of Sec. 29, T. 47 N., R. 2 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thin A1 horizons or C horizons occur in some pedons.  These soils are noncalcareous throughout.  Base saturation ranges from 60 to 100 percent in all subhorizons of the argillic horizon.  Depth to the fragmental IIC horizons ranges from 20 to 40 inches.  Depth to the top of the argillic horizon is less than 24 inches, and depth to the base of the argillic horizon ranges from 17 to 40 inches.  Rock fragments range from 35 to 75 percent in a major part of the solum and any C horizon and are mainly 10 to 40 inches in diameter.  The solum ranges from medium acid through mildly alkaline.  The mean annual soil temperature is 38 degrees F., and the mean summer soil temperature is 46 degrees F., with an 0 horizon 4 inches thick.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR through 5YR, value of 5 through 8 dry, 4 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 4.
The B2t horizon has hue of 5YR through 10R, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 1 through 6.  It is typically very stony or extremely stony clay loam, clay, or sandy clay and the fine earth fraction has 35 to 50 percent clay, 5 to 40 percent silt, and 15 to 55 percent sand with more than 15 percent being fine or coarser sand.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Chris, Nutras and Seitz series. These soils lack fragmental IIC horizons at depths of less than 50 inches.  Also, Chris soils have coarse fragments mainly less than 10 inches in diameter and Seitz soils have hue of 7.5YR or yellower in the B2t horizon.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Vulcan soils are on gently to steeply sloping mesa tops and sides.  Slope gradients range from 2 to 30 or more percent.  The soils formed in very stony parent materials weathered from highly fractured rhyolite or similar bedrock.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is 20 inches with peak periods of precipitation occurring during the spring and summer. The mean annual temperature is 34 degrees F., mean summer temperature is 47 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Nutras soils and the Ruby soils.  Ruby soils have mollic epipedons and lack A2 horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for forestry, native pastureland, or for recreational purposes.  Native vegetation is mainly Douglas-fir, Engelmann spruce, aspen and common juniper with a weak understory of grasses and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas of central Colorado. The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  OSED scanned by NSSQA and cleaned up by Colorado.  Last revised by state 8/74.
